div.head: Victoria College.
SECOND ANNUAL REPORT.
div.p: If an ^institution is privileged from its birth to arouse the enthusiasm of generous friends, it may be predicted that its future will at least be interesting ; Mid if the institution, as it grows older, earns the additional privilege of provoking the attention of watchful critics. it may be assumed that it is alive and doing »..rk in the world. .In the full belief that Victoria t' i.i.K>;r. is not only alive but growing stronger the' headmaster presents the second annual report to the Committee, the members of which, ho is persuaded,' will ,,gr.v with him in holding that, while the functions' ,,f riticisro and enthusiasm are different enough, the province of eaeh^fs the same, and that since both tnbly are exercised in the interests of tho school, it i, n«.t to its advantage to be deprived of the assistance of either. f' *

div.head: INTRODUCTfTRY.
div.p: it will be remembered tf|st the CocMiitteo, en- - ;raged bv the results of *i»e first ^voar’s work, • i..d r.. build an upper story foV '.fciftlcrs, and that v ui arrangement with the Municipality of Alexandria the level of the playground was to he lowered. In consequence of these improvements and alterations the 13th f October had been'fixed as the earliest day on which the school could, be re-opened. As that date drt-w close, it was thought by many that neither the budding nor the playground would be ready. The upper story did not present a hopeful appearance, the playground had been converted into a somewhat com- plieitted system of light railways, the front door hung d/jeetedly in' mid-air and the only entrance to the eiissrooms was by escalade. Goodwill, however, ,did ^ nders. Mr. Borg, the caj«blc representative of Messrs. Met‘lure and Dorling, pressed on the "ork upstairs, Mi October 15th Mes-r- Almagia were obliging as to drive a cutting which made it possible to enter the school by the Wck door. and in spite of the pessimists the -chord opened •[, tin appointed day

div.head: STATISTICS.
div.p: In such circumstances it was not expected that the entry -t new Is.y- would >-• largo. A« a matter of fact it readied the «aimtactory total of 27, of whom 7 were l-.ard.-rs The f-h.-.l therefore at the beginning jf its second year r.uubercd 6»> hoy-, an increase of 41 «inoe NoVemts-r l-.a.g Besides tins useful Addition to the number of j. ,] ;|- there had U-en an iin|-:>rtaiil addition • the 'tat* l |.o„ the nomination of the Blaster Mr A Morn-..,,. M A . -.Jetime scholar and riz.-Rian t King- t >-liege, t am bridge. Mr. Morrison oii.-e . t.lered uj-.n hi- duties in the be«t spirit and t.y ht« tie-rough and eon-cietitioiis work in -clmol, and n- friendly interest in the games, -oon w..,i the cf.n idence and iitfection ..f hi- pti]iil-. A second new aetuber f the -tnti. voluntary but not the less helpful) so- Mis» Lias, who beside- superintending all the I the hoarders' found time to take a class of small «• y- :n elementary English. The headmaster having --u ii.formed that it would 1»> impossible for an Englishwoman to take a useful part in the teaching H I management of « boys' school in Egypt, is glad " he able/ state that this has not Wen hi- exueriein-e

div.head: THE SCHOOLS PROGRESS.
div.p: • i Is-t years report a narrative was given of tho e-.-nt- of .diool year. It is not how proposed to t>- . tale which must of necessity to some extent ;t-elf. Such a recital might easily convey a in -- impression of school life with «1l\ its manifold interest- apparently indeed the same, but ever varying •n detail from day to day. Moreover since the school

is now full, profitable as'it always is to., look back upon the experience and lessons of the pust, u-is even more essential to look forwanl to'the problems of the future, For these reasons the survey of the year must be brief. The work continued on the lines already- laid down. A fourth form was constituted, and it should here be stated for tlicrhciiefit of those to whom English nomenclature is unfamiliar that the word “form” or bench corresponds to the expression “year” in use at the primary and secondary- schools of .thqf Egyptian Government. The first form is accordingly the lowest, euid not the .highest in the school.

div.head: SCHOOL ORGANISATION.
div.p: To these four forms it is intended to add an- otherj^/ear* by year, as the age of the pupils in- crea$es^un$il ultimately a course shall have been providoirivwlrteh will give efficient instruction to boys between the ages of seven and eighteen years. With four classes it was possible t attempt a somewhat more ambitious programme. The difference in knowledge between boys in the first and fourth form will best be grasped by a reference to the scheme (p. 23) which presents in tabular form a conspectus of the work done throughout the school. From a very humble beginning in the first form, (in which h»w-ver it is claimed thut solid foundations are laid, and in which boys should if possible begin their school life) the work reaches u quite respectable level in the fourth form. The subjects taught included all those of last year with the addition of a course of elementary- practical Geometry successfully -undertaken by Mr. Luiuclj. In addition to the useful monthly examinations, which nave become a feature of the school work, a general examination of the whole school was held in the second Week of Julv,

div.head: EXAMS.
div.p: The examination was conducted l.y the masters themselves, each of whom examine.I ..rally and by written questions the pupils whom lie had been teaching during the year. Such an arrnuge- ment, honestly carried out, lias much in its favour, for.jio. one i- I totter aide to sound by appropriate questions the depth- of a boy’- ignorance or knowledge than the master who has been face to face with his difficulties throughout the year Thut this examination was hone-tly dp.-ted will be vouched for not only by the l-.vs themselves, but by Mr. Gould, who kindly l«nd the school uu official visit and sati-ficiLdiimseli ..the subject »>f examination happened,, that /tiny to be composition, thut the boy- received m> a-istance in their work. Tho headmaster i- aware, however, tha parent- look for some outside testimony, and with the help ..f Mr. Gould he is trying to arrange that the annual examination of the school shall be conducted' by the Oxford und Cambridge .'schools Examination board, the Higher Certificate of which gives exemption from all the important preliminary examinations in England. If this arrangement can be curried out, the pupils of the school will l>e entered for an excellent examination, and in the event of their Is-ing successful, parents will have not only u guarantee that the work of the school is good, but a certificate which will ciiuhle their sons, if they so desire, to continue their studies either at English medical and engineering schools, or 1 .etter still, at the two great English Universities.

div.head: THE RESULTS.
div.p: Returning to tho examinations of last summer, the results were read out to the boys before the school broke up. Especial mention must be made of the excellent work of G. Valassopoulo, M. Antonius, G. Antonius and E. Harle in the IV. Form, of A. Nimr, F. Stent, R. Tuby in the HI. Form, and of J. Lascaridis in the II. Form. Solid work was also done by some who were not so fortunate as to win prize*; among these may- bo mentioned in the fourth form form S. Checri and U. Prangi ; and in the third form J. Tuby, A. G. I’saltis and E. Cordahi, all of whom

worked steadily throughout the year. On the whole the results obtained were ver^ encouraging to the masters. In French the boys did particularly well under M. Dumont whose methods and discipline have won the approval of those most competent to judge. In English the progress of almost all the boys was (it is no exaggeration to say) astonishing. Iu Mathematics, History and Geography satisfactory results were obtained, and in Drawing some good work was done for Mr. Mustard who had taken much trouble in teaching this important subject Of the boys

div.head: PROFICIENCY IN ARABIC.
div.p: the headmaster is not yet qualified to speak. It is therefore with all the more satisfaction that he is able to report that in the opinion of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Shawiah, who is now assisting the Professors of Arabic at Oxford, the standard reached in Arabic is remarkably good, especially in consideration of the fact that to so many of the boys Arabic is a foreign tongue. The headmaster wishes to take this opportunity of thanking Sheikh Mohammed Hamed, who has succeeded not only in teaching those to whom Arabic is their mother tongue but also in inspiring others, to whom it is an exceedingly difficult aqd at first even a repellent language, with a desire to advance beyond the threshhold. The thanks of the Committee are also due in an especial degree to Sheikh Abdul Aziz Shawish for his kindness in putting the boys of the third anti fourth forms through a searching oral examination.

div.head: PRIVATE READING.
div.p: As supplementary \to work in school, which is necessarily restricted in its scope, everything |(ossible has been done to encourage the private reading of the ptipil.s. However much a master may help a boy by his teaching, the boy, ifv’properly directed, can. Jo much more for himself. But in order to read profitable books it is necessary to have access to a library. Victoria College is still in .its infancy, and a school library does not yet exist. Something however in the way of creating one has been done by the boys themselves and something has been done by their friends. In last year's report mention was made of lending library, rendered possible in the first instance by grfta from the National Bank and Mr. Alderson. This year the headmaster has the pleasure to record further gifts and donations. The Earl’ of Meath, to whom the school is also indebted for a Howard Vincent Map and a dummy rifle, very kindly presented a copy of 'Milner'* England in Egypt, and among other gifts there were £5 from, an anonymous donor and £10 from Dr. Morrison, who in this and in other ways has proved a very generous friend to the school. The lending library now numbers over 200 volumes and possesses many useful books of reference. It is pleAsant to be able to state that the' latter arc in constant requisition, and it is to be hoped that it may be passible some slay to add to their number.

div.head: GAMES AND DRILL.
div.p: Out of school the boys had their time well occupied with games and drill—too much time it has been complained by some. But in the opinion of the headmaster, who on this subject errs, if error it bo, in good company, long school hours defeat their own object. Boys, discouraged bj/tho teaching of lessons which seem to have no ejtd, allow their attention to wander in school, while (out of doors they lose their natural aptitude for play and exercise. It has been said of the Japanese soldier, that when ho is not energetically and cheerfully at work, he is energetically and cheerfully at/play. This is an ideal which with some other manly virtues wo may well borrow from that gallant People. The very important work of supervision again fell principally upon Mr. Mustard and Mr. I/owjck, who once more undertook the duties of drill instructors, entering very heartily into a difficult, and sometimes discouraging work. In this they were materially assisted by two of the senior bdys, T. Checri,

and A. Vorny, who developed into two smart corporals. The two companies, as last year, had the honour of lysing inspected by the Earl of Meath, who with Iauly Meath visited the school in the Spring, It .was encouraging /to the instructors to bo informed that since the last inspection there had been a very marked" improvement. The thanks of the Committee are due to Mr. Mustard and Mr. Lowick not only for acting as drill instructors, but also for undertaking again the supervision of the playground and the omnibus, duties which, entailing no little sacrifice of personal comfort, have contributed very much to the efficiency of the school.

div.head: ATHLETICS.
div.p: The games, that important department of a boy’s life, have grown into a serious institution. Hockey found its proper place in tho season which intervenes between football and cricket, though these two games, as in England had the larger number of partisans. At football the school XI., not flying at the highest game, escaped defeat, and at cricket a new departure was made. Thanks to the kindness of the Alexandria C. C. represented by its captain Mr. T. H. Marsden, and its Hon. Secretary Mr. F. G. Freeman, the boys were able to play once a fortnight on the excellent ground belonging to the Club—a privilege which they thoroughly appreciated. Mr. Marsden and Mr. Freeman did so much to make the cricket of the school a success that the warmest thanks of all are due to them and also to another enthusiastic member of the Club, Mr. F. W. Carver, who presented the school with £20 to be devoted to games. The money has been spent on two asphalt pitches, which it will be possible to use all the year round. The balanco which remains will also be laid out on improvements in the playground, possibly in the purchase of iron stanchions and a rope to enclose the football ground and mark out a running track.

div.head: 80ME INCIDENTS.
div.p: Although it has not been thought necessary to describe at length the routine of the school year, it would not bo right to pasx oyer without mention the incidents which most strike the imagination of the boys. To the visit of Lord and Lad.v Meath allusion has already been made. The school was also honoured on April 28th by the visit of Lord and Lady Cromer, aocompanied on this occasion by Mr. and Mrs. Gould, and received on behalf > of the Committee by Mr. Alderson, Mr. Kingham and Mr. Preston. The visit was especially interesting to everyone as this was the first occasion on which Lady Cromer had had the opportunity of seeing the school, since the foundation stone was laid. Lord Cromer as usual made a very close inspection of the boys and of the buildings. His criticisms were brief and to the- point. “The boys," he said, “looked happy and the playground bare.” The headmaster has reason to believe that Lord Cromer was pleased witja the intelligence as well as the 'appearance of the boys and ho may perhaps be allowed to repeat that the Committee has good reason to be grateful for the interest which Lord Cromer has constantly shown in the school. Again and again ho has been assured by pareuts that to them there is no Jbetter guarantee of the usefulness of the school than the visits of Lord Cromer and his reference to the school in his annual Reports.

div.head: THE KINDERGARTEN.
div.p: It must not be supposed that the headmaster in speaking of the success of the school so far is unaware of the weaknesses which exist. But with the means at tho disposal of the Committee everything possible has been done. The Kindergarten recommended last year has been built and the circular announcing its' proposed establishment has had a most encourag­ing response. It is ndt, however, yet certain whether it will be possible to open the Kindergarten at all, and that for two reasons: first, because among the applicants are many little girls (the question immediately arises to what school can they go when they have passed/the Kindergarten age 1), and secondly because Victoria College itself is full. The entries this year number 54 and tho building intended for the Kindergarten provides tho only classroom into which it is possible to overflow. To what has this success been due 1 Partly to the enoouragement and Bupjwrt to which reference has already been made, partly to the admir­able position of the school by the sea, to the well arranged classrooms and spacious playground (which the Committee has so wisely enclosed), and partly to the fact that English education for boys and girls is called for throughout the country with no uncertain voice. For two years the masters have worked hard and cheerfully for the good of the school. The future is not in their hands. In tho brief sketch which follows an attempt has been made to show where in the opiuion of the headmaster this future lies.

div.head: THE REFLECTIONS OP MR. LIAS.
div.p: An Englishman, if he were asked what he thought uost characteristics of tho institution peculiar to his ountry, would perhaps reply that it was their power to stand the test of time; and if he were further esked to give a reason for this vitality his answer might be that English institutions based upon the bed­rock of experience and susceptible of modifications as the nature of the case required, had possibly not yet attained the limits of their natural growth. The truth is that profiting by the lessons of the Norman Conquest, Englishmen, victors and vanquished alike, out off geographically from the rest of the world, learned betimes to estimate at its true value tho homely lesson of give and take. First in the State and afterwards in tho Church compromise has been the keystone of our national polity and it is the readinesa to compromise which is still one of the secrets of our national strength.
To bt continvtd.)
